body:
### Problem

If a buffer has a `buftype`, LSP won't attach to it without manually calling `vim.lsp.start` (see #36599 for context.)
This is by design, because plugin can require scratch buffers for processing or whatever and attaching lsp there would tank performances.

### Expected behavior

There should be a way to whitelist a buffer into the auto-attach logic, maybe something as simple as adding a buffer local variable like `b:lsp-autoattach = true`.

Implementation would just add a `and` here: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/c4ac36bfd9bc9826dde01839d10d0e65a7b3c9e2/runtime/lua/vim/lsp.lua#L475-L477

comment_data.body:
I think, if implemented, this should be an option given to commands that create a scratch buffer, not something you set after. Because:

1. You can already have the desired behavior if you simulate a scratch buffer from a normal buffer while minding that `filetype` that triggers the check is set before `buftype`:

```lua
local function scratch()
  -- create normal buffer
  local buf = vim.api.nvim_create_buf(false, false)
  -- set filetype which would trigger lsp
  vim.bo[buf].filetype = "json"
  -- simulate scratch buffer
  vim.bo[buf].buftype = "nofile"
  vim.bo[buf].bufhidden = "hide"
  vim.bo[buf].swapfile = false
  -- lsp is attached
  vim.api.nvim_set_current_buf(buf)
end
```

2. You won't have desired behavior on a scratch buffer with the new `lsp-autoattach` if you set it later than something that checks the condition:

```lua
local function scratch()
  -- create scratch buffer
  local buf = vim.api.nvim_create_buf(false, true)
  -- set filetype which would trigger lsp
  vim.bo[buf].filetype = "json"
  -- set option too late :(
  vim.bo[buf].lsp_autoattach = true
  -- lsp is not attached
  vim.api.nvim_set_current_buf(buf)
end
```

So instead it could be `vim.api.nvim_create_buf(<listed>, <scratch>, [<allow_lsp>])`. **However**, your suggestion about a separate option is good because it persists. Which means, if there is a plugin that lets you save scratch buffers between sessions, the LSP will attach on restore as well. So maybe we should have both.
That's exactly why my first example has both options set to false, so scratch buffer is simulated after LSP attaches. What's your point?

> So instead it could be `vim.api.nvim_create_buf(<listed>, <scratch>, [<allow_lsp>])`

Sounds like a new 'buftype' could make sense. Or maybe there is an existing buftype(s) that LSP should already support (by updating the above condition).

> Sounds like a new 'buftype' could make sense. Or maybe there is an existing buftype(s) that LSP should already support (by updating the above condition).

I think we do need to have a feature-rich user-facing type, and a blank-slate utility type.

Making a new `buftype` seems to be the most straightforward solution, if there are no worries about backwards compatibility. All of my scripts focus on checking that `buftype` is empty. I have no idea if that set of values is historically stable.

Alternatively, if provided with enough localopts, users could combine things on their own, the same way `special-buffers` combine options into ephemeral concepts of "directory" and "scratch". But there is a challenge of making options apply at the right time, and making them cover very specific domains (`:setlocal nolspable` ðŸ˜‚).

> Sounds like a new 'buftype' could make sense. 

One problem with a dedicated buftype is that you can have a server that can attach to scratch buffers, and another server that can't, but both are for the same filetype. Then you can also have special type of scratch buffers that a server can attach to, while having others that it can't attach to. E.g. jdtls can attach to `jdt://` buffers which e.g. nvim-jdtls opens as `buftype=nofile`, but it can't attach to any arbitrary java scratch buffer.

The other aspect is the impact this has on plugins which currently check buftypes for whatever reason.

And that it doesn't compose. E.g. with `buftype=acwrite` - which I use for `dap-eval://` buffers, which luals for example can attach to.

Imho we should support something like:

```lua
vim.lsp.get_config(name, function(conf)
  vim.lsp.start(conf)
end)
```

To make it easier to handle the async properties of a config (currently root_dir), and then people can go nuts using ftplugin autocmd + some `if` conditions to guard the lsp.start call. No need to special case every possible scenario.

---

Also note that if you already have a custom function to create a scratch buffer, if you know which server you want to attach to it, you could bootstrap the language server more directly using something like:

```lua
local buf = ... -- logic to create buffer
local clients = vim.lsp.get_clients({ name = "myserver" })
if next(clients) then
  for _, client in ipairs(client) do
    vim.lsp.buf_attach_client(buf, client.id)
  end
else
  vim.lsp.start(...)
end
```

(untested)

> Imho we should support something like:
> 
> vim.lsp.get_config(name, function(conf)
>   vim.lsp.start(conf)
> end)

Is that covered by, or a potential sub-task of, the "Allow Config to be a function (instead of a LspConfig table)" [proposal](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/33577#issuecomment-3568292351)?

> you can have a server that can attach to scratch buffers, and another server that can't...

> the impact this has on plugins which currently check buftypes for whatever reason...

> you could bootstrap the language server...

It looks like starting with a no-file buffer requires many fixes just to make it behave like a normal buffer. Maybe I'm missing the point, but are native scratchpads as a class worth it then? They don't promise sandboxing or anything unique... 

One could just create `~/.cache/nvim/scratch/` and make "scratchpads" be created there under names/subfolders hashed based on datetime, uuidgen or something. Clearing such cache automatically or on demand is quite simple, and most session managers can be instructed to ignore certain paths.

> One could just create `~/.cache/nvim/scratch/` and make "scratchpads" be created there under names/subfolders hashed based on datetime, uuidgen or something.

That shifts the problem to a different place. And removes (or changes) the mechanism for identifying "scratchpads".

The point about some servers not working on non-files is substantial. And I also imagine someone coming here in a year asking to be able to save or at least lsp-format a scratch buffer. All I'm saying, there are better options for making temporary files, if that's what constitutes a "scratchpad" in this case.

If a scratchpad would mean something similar to sandboxing / separate OS process / incognito mode, this hack would not work. But otherwise, why invent a buftype that behaves like a normal buffer just to hide its physical location or save an IO call or two, you know...

---
EDIT

For example, the benefit of a scratch buffer could be that it always starts a separate server. Although, this could be done manually as well, by making one setup for regular buffers with a filter against certain path, and one with disabled workspace settings and a filter targeting that cache path. So nothing is impossible in principal, and much more customizable this way. So idk.

> All I'm saying, there are better options for making temporary files, if that's what constitutes a "scratchpad" in this case.

That just means plugins will have to find a new way to identify "scratchpad", so again, it shifts the problem around.

> > Imho we should support something like:
> > vim.lsp.get_config(name, function(conf)
> > vim.lsp.start(conf)
> > end)
> 
> Is that covered by, or a potential sub-task of, the "Allow Config to be a function (instead of a LspConfig table)" [proposal](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/33577#issuecomment-3568292351)?

Seems like it. Yes. 

The whole issue here was btw. also discussed in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/32037 - but I kinda lost the overview.

> plugin can require scratch buffers for processing or whatever

Oh, I read it as "plugin needs to **create** a scratch buffer", which would just mean they keep their own cache, and empty it on VimLeave or something.

If it meant "plugin needs to **identify** scratch buffers", then some sort of marker is needed. But that can be done by a custom buflocal option, since ways to classify such buffers are endless.

We have no idea what is the actual plugin the author had in mind. If it's something in the nature of `float-term` but for scratch buffers with LSP support, this:

> ```lua
> vim.lsp.get_config(name, function(conf)
>   vim.lsp.start(conf)
> end)
>```

solves nothing, because there is no single LSP to target.

However, we mark a discussion about what "scratch" type should mean in Neovim "off-topic" because it's not in line with the quick hack we have in mind. Good job! That's the way to build a user-facing product.

Neither this:

```text
:setlocal buftype=nofile
:setlocal bufhidden=hide
:setlocal noswapfile
```
nor this:
```text
Creates a "throwaway" |scratch-buffer| for temporary work
(always 'nomodified'). Also sets 'nomodeline' on the buffer.
```
suggests that LSP or other things should be enabled or disabled for a buffer.

More than that, this issue already has several workarounds. The problem is with classification and its implications, not the lack of API that does the same thing in three lines of code instead of five.

---

Don't worry, I'll see myself out.

> However, we mark a discussion about what "scratch" type should mean in Neovim "off-topic" because it's not in line with the quick hack we have in mind. Good job! That's the way to build a user-facing product.

I am simply trying to make sense of which parts of this discussion are relevant. There are 1700 open issues and we need to maintain signal-to-noise.

Nobody here is looking for a quick hack, obviously. But we are looking for things that are composable and fit in with existing conventions.

> solves nothing, because there is no single LSP to target.

As I was explaining in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/36775#issuecomment-3602453145, whether a language server can attach to a buffer or not also depends on the server, not only on the buffer. Some servers require files to exist on the filesystem to function, others don't. 

You can't put the decision if a buffer is attachable for LSP solely to the buffer, it needs to be part of server specific configuration. 

The only question here is to what degree we make configuring that more ergonomic. We could go the route of https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/32037, or the one I proposed here. The trade-off is one is more specific and likely more convenient for users, the other is more flexible but requires a line or two more.

> Imho we should support something like:
> 
> vim.lsp.get_config(name, function(conf)
>   vim.lsp.start(conf)
> end)

This would be great in general for users who like to use ftplugin files for triggering LSP.

This would also open up a use case where, say you wanted to make a plugin that uses an in-process LSP to enhance help file navigation - You could package an ftplugin file that triggers the LSP to start, which would work even though help files have a non-blank buftype.

From the plugin dev perspective - user LSPs not starting on non-blank buftypes is an important assumption to be able to make. If a user is starting LSPs on non-blank buftypes, it should be assumed they are taking responsibility for what they are doing.
